questions.text: A mother presents with a 3-week-old infant expressing excessive concern about harming her baby. questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postpartum psychosis is usually seen within 2-3 weeks of delivery . Initial symptoms include tearfulness, insomnia, and lability. Later delusions (e.g. baby is dead, didn’t give birth to a child) and hallucinations develop. There is a risk of harm to self or the baby . In some cases, the baby has to be separated from the mother to prevent harm to the baby. Treatment includes the use of antipsychotics with lithium; antidepressants may be added if required.
  • ➤ Postpartum psychosis is usually seen within 2-3 weeks of delivery . Initial symptoms include tearfulness, insomnia, and lability.
  • ➤ Postpartum psychosis

  • ➤ delusions

  • ➤ There is a risk of harm to self or the baby . In some cases, the baby has to be separated from the mother to prevent harm to the baby.
  • ➤ risk of harm to self or the baby
  • ➤ Treatment includes the use of antipsychotics with lithium; antidepressants may be added if required.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic atrial fibrillation is scheduled for a total knee arthroplasty. He is currently managed on warfarin therapy, which has been held for the past 5 days. Preoperative labs show a platelet count of 85,000/mm^3, and he reports taking aspirin up until two days ago. Considering his medication history and lab findings, which of the following would generally not be a contraindication to performing central neuraxial anesthesia in this patient?
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Aspirin alters platelet function but is not an absolute contraindication for central neuraxial anesthesia, particularly if discontinued a few days before the procedure and in the absence of other bleeding risks. Each patient must be assessed individually, taking into consideration current guidelines and clinical judgment.
  • ➤ Aspirin alters platelet function but is not an absolute contraindication for central neuraxial anesthesia, particularly if discontinued a few days before the procedure and in the absence of other bleeding risks. questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with developmental delay, hyperactivity, and difficulty maintaining eye contact. On examination, he has a long face, large protruding ears, and macroorchidism. His family history reveals a maternal uncle with similar symptoms. Genetic testing is performed, revealing an abnormal FMR1 gene. Which of the following statements is true about Fragile X syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Males have IQ 20–40

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that Fragile X syndrome is caused by CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene, leading to hypermethylation and gene silencing. It predominantly affects males, with IQ typically in the range of 20–40, and is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability. Differentiate it from other trinucleotide repeat disorders like Huntington’s disease.
  • ➤ Understand that Fragile X syndrome is caused by CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene, leading to hypermethylation and gene silencing.
  • ➤ It predominantly affects males, with IQ typically in the range of 20–40, and is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability.
  • ➤ Differentiate it from other trinucleotide repeat disorders like Huntington’s disease.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department by parents who report that during the recent fever episode, the child experienced a convulsion. Ans. A) Furosemide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Furosemide is a loop diuretic that reduces potassium levels by increasing its excretion, whereas beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, and ARBs can increase potassium levels due to their effects on renal function and electrolyte balance.
  • ➤ Furosemide is a loop diuretic that reduces potassium levels by increasing its excretion, whereas beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, and ARBs can increase potassium levels due to their effects on renal function and electrolyte balance.

questions.text: A 17-year-old presents with primary amenorrhea. Physical examination shows normal genitalia and breast development. Laboratory results reveal a 5-alpha reductase deficiency. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Male pseudohermaphrodite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 5-alpha reductase deficiency causes male pseudohermaphroditism , characterized by a 46,XY karyotype with ambiguous or female-like genitalia due to impaired DHT production. At puberty, testosterone-driven virilization may occur, revealing the underlying condition.
  • ➤ 5-alpha reductase deficiency causes male pseudohermaphroditism , characterized by a 46,XY karyotype with ambiguous or female-like genitalia due to impaired DHT production.
  • ➤ 5-alpha reductase deficiency
  • ➤ male pseudohermaphroditism
  • ➤ At puberty, testosterone-driven virilization may occur, revealing the underlying condition.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with recurrent infections involving the lungs, liver, and bones that have required multiple hospitalizations. His history is significant for excessive inflammation, granuloma formation, gingivitis, aphthous ulcers, and seborrheic dermatitis. Laboratory testing shows defective respiratory burst activity in neutrophils. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes is responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) NADPH oxidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) results from a deficiency of NADPH oxidase , which impairs the respiratory burst in phagocytes, leading to defective microbial killing, recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms, and granuloma formation .
  • ➤ Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) results from a deficiency of NADPH oxidase , which impairs the respiratory burst in phagocytes, leading to defective microbial killing, recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms, and granuloma formation .
  • ➤ Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD)
  • ➤ NADPH oxidase
  • ➤ granuloma formation

questions.text: Following the consumption of a heavy meal with an alcoholic binge, a patient presents with severe chest pain and retching. Serum lipase is 200U/L, chest X-ray shows left pleural effusion. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Boerhaave’s syndrome presents with a triad of vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema , often after forceful retching following heavy meals or alcohol binge. CECT thorax + abdomen with contrast is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis, identify the perforation site, and detect complications like pleural effusion or mediastinitis.
  • ➤ Boerhaave’s syndrome presents with a triad of vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema , often after forceful retching following heavy meals or alcohol binge.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with generalized muscle weakness and fatigue that worsens with activity and improves with rest. She also reports diplopia and ptosis. Initial testing reveals a negative serum anti-AChR antibody test. Further investigations reveal the presence of anti-MuSK antibodies. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of anti-MuSK antibodies excludes the possibility of anti-AChR antibodies in other patients.

options.label: B
options.text: Anti-MuSK antibodies are commonly found in patients with weakness confined to ocular muscles.

options.label: C
options.text: Anti-MuSK antibodies are present in approximately 40% of anti-AChR antibody-negative patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (MG).

options.label: D
options.text: The severity of myasthenia gravis correlates directly with the measured level of anti-AChR antibodies.

questions.correct_answer: C. Anti-MuSK antibodies are present in approximately 40% of anti-AChR antibody-negative patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (MG).
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anti-MuSK antibodies are present in approximately 40% of anti-AChR antibody-negative patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (MG).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with generalized MG who are negative for anti-AChR antibodies may have anti-MuSK antibodies . These antibodies play a significant role in the clustering of acetylcholine receptors and are critical for diagnosing antibody-negative MG.
  • ➤ Patients with generalized MG who are negative for anti-AChR antibodies may have anti-MuSK antibodies .
  • ➤ generalized MG
  • ➤ anti-MuSK antibodies
  • ➤ These antibodies play a significant role in the clustering of acetylcholine receptors and are critical for diagnosing antibody-negative MG.

options.label: C
options.text: Ischemic damage due to systemic vasculitis

options.label: D
options.text: Acute tubular necrosis due to toxic metabolites

questions.correct_answer: C. Ischemic damage due to systemic vasculitis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ischemic damage due to systemic vasculitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Weil's disease

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with severe agitation, fever of 103°F (39.4°C), tachycardia, and tremors. Her medical history is significant for untreated hyperthyroidism. Laboratory studies reveal suppressed TSH and elevated free T3 and T4 levels. A diagnosis of thyroid storm is made. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in the treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aspirin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspirin is contraindicated in thyroid storm because it displaces thyroid hormones from their binding proteins, potentially worsening the condition. Acetaminophen is preferred for managing fever in this situation.
  • ➤ Aspirin is contraindicated in thyroid storm because it displaces thyroid hormones from their binding proteins, potentially worsening the condition.
  • ➤ Acetaminophen is preferred for managing fever in this situation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female, a healthcare worker, presents for a routine check-up. She reports no major symptoms but is concerned about a recent needle-stick injury during a patient procedure. Laboratory tests reveal normal liver enzymes, but she tests positive for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) with elevated levels of anti-HBc IgG antibodies. Despite these findings, her viral load remains detectable. What is the most likely reason for her persistent viremia despite the presence of these antibodies?

options.label: A
options.text: Antigenic variation in the hepatitis B virus surface antigen

options.label: B
options.text: Immune complex formation with hepatitis B surface antigen

options.label: C
options.text: Inefficient B-cell response to the hepatitis B virus

options.label: D
options.text: Non-neutralizing antibodies against the hepatitis B virus surface antigen

questions.correct_answer: D. Non-neutralizing antibodies against the hepatitis B virus surface antigen
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Non-neutralizing antibodies against the hepatitis B virus surface antigen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In chronic hepatitis B infection, non-neutralizing antibodies against hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) can be present and fail to clear the virus, leading to persistent viremia despite the presence of specific antibodies. This highlights the importance of the neutralizing capacity of antibodies in controlling viral infections.
  • ➤ In chronic hepatitis B infection, non-neutralizing antibodies against hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) can be present and fail to clear the virus, leading to persistent viremia despite the presence of specific antibodies. This highlights the importance of the neutralizing capacity of antibodies in controlling viral infections.
  • ➤ hepatitis B
  • ➤ non-neutralizing antibodies
  • ➤ hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg)
  • ➤ persistent viremia
  • ➤ neutralizing capacity

questions.text: All of the following can differentiate between Yersinia enterocolitica and Yersinia pestis except:

Ans. A) Presence of lactose fermentation on MacConkey agar

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Both Yersinia enterocolitica and Yersinia pestis are non-lactose fermenters on MacConkey agar, so lactose fermentation cannot be used to differentiate between them.
  • • Key differentiating features between the two include:
  • • Key differentiating features between the two include:
  • • Motility at 22°C: Y. enterocolitica is motile at 22°C, whereas Y. pestis is non-motile at all temperatures.
  • • Motility at 22°C:
  • • Growth at 4°C: Y. enterocolitica can grow at refrigeration temperatures (psychrophilic), while Y. pestis cannot.
  • • Growth at 4°C:
  • • Urease activity: Y. enterocolitica is urease-positive, while Y. pestis is urease-negative.
  • • Urease activity:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Yersinia enterocolitica and Yersinia pestis differ in motility at 22°C, growth at 4°C, and urease activity. However, both are non-lactose fermenters on MacConkey agar, making lactose fermentation an invalid differentiating factor.

questions.text: A ten-year-old boy presents with a right-sided acute scrotal pain. Examination reveals tenderness which worsens on lifting the testis. Which of these is the most common anatomical abnormality responsible for this condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. High investment of tunica vaginalis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) High investment of tunica vaginalis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High investment of the tunica vaginalis, also called the bell-clapper deformity , is the most common anatomical abnormality leading to testicular torsion . It allows excessive testicular mobility, causing rotation around the spermatic cord, vascular compromise, and acute scrotal pain.
  • ➤ High investment of the tunica vaginalis, also called the bell-clapper deformity , is the most common anatomical abnormality leading to testicular torsion .
  • ➤ bell-clapper deformity
  • ➤ testicular torsion
  • ➤ It allows excessive testicular mobility, causing rotation around the spermatic cord, vascular compromise, and acute scrotal pain.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of epilepsy and hypertension presents with progressive shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough.
